article.para: Since May 2005, SuperTux sports a Squirrel scripting interface useful for level designers who want to add some interactive pep to their levels. This document poses as a reference article for those who want to explore the various objects of the SuperTux scripting model.

sect1.title: What is Squirrel?
sect1.para: One of your first questions might be, "What does a rodent have to do with a penguin?" Squirrel is a language with a syntax not much unlike other C-like languages (C, C++, Java, ...). In the current implementation, it is integrated as elements in the SuperTux level files.

sect1.title: Squirrel, Scheme and SuperTux
sect1.para:
I have no clue if the developers simply chose Squirrel just because the name so nicely integrates into the series of words "SuperTux" and "Scheme". Currently, the Squirrel code is integrated in string arguments of Scheme elements in SuperTux level files. (Whew.) This is an example code block inside a level: (supertux-level (version 2) (name _("Go Blind")) (author "Team") (sector (name "main") (music "Annoying_penguin_gawking_sounds.mod")
;; (Tilemaps, objects, whatever.)
(init-script " DisplayEffect.fade_out(2.5); ") ) ) When this level loads, the screen fades out completely during two and a half seconds right after the level is loaded. (Mind you, this would be a frustrating experience for the player if you add a horde of badguys near the spawn point.)

sect1.title: Object reference
sect1.para: If you are interested in an object and what cans of worms you can open with it, this section is for you.

"(NYI)" after the function name symbolises functions that haven't been implemented yet. Calling them will result in a line being printed to standard output informing anybody who reads it that the script is using a function that actually doesn't exist. (Win32 users will happily ignore this, because they simply start the application by opening it with Explorer. Unix users are going to be more interested in what SuperTux can actually tell them, so it's better if you don't use non-existent functions in your scripts.)

sect2.title: Global Constants
sect2.para: These constants can be accessed from anywhere in the game code.

sect2.title: Global Functions
sect2.para: These global functions access basic or generic methods of SuperTux. They are called without an object name.

sect3.title: display_text_file
sect3.para: Displays the SuperTux text file named filename. (The path is relative to the level file.)
See also: SuperTux file format reference, SuperTux texts

sect3.title: wait
sect3.para: Pauses execution of the squirrel code for time seconds.

sect3.title: translate
sect3.para: Translates text into the user's locale.
Note: This construct is unfortunately not yet recognised by XGetText, so translation files have to be written manually.

sect3.title: import
sect3.para: Imports and runs the Squirrel script filename. (The path is relative to the level file.)

sect3.title: add_key
sect3.para: Adds or removes a key from the player's posession. key should be replaced with one of the KEY_ constants.

sect2.title: DisplayEffect
sect2.para: DisplayEffect is an interface for toying with the display.

sect3.title: fade_out
sect3.para: Gradually fades out the screen to black for the next fadetime seconds.

sect3.title: fade_in
sect3.para: Gradually fades in the screen from black for the next fadetime seconds.

sect3.title: set_black
sect3.para: Blackens or un-blackens the screen (depending on the value of black).

sect3.title: is_black
sect3.para: Returns true if the screen has been blackened by set_black. Calling fade_in or fade_out resets the return value to false.

sect3.title: sixteen_to_nine
sect3.para: Sets the display ratio to 16:9, effectively adding black bars at the top and bottom of the screen. Should be used before cutscenes.

sect3.title: four_to_three
sect3.para: Sets the display ratio to 4:3, removing the black bars added by sixteen_to_nine(). Should be used after cutscenes.

sect2.title: Camera
sect2.para: Camera is an interface to manipulate the camera.

sect3.title: shake (NYI)
sect3.para: Usage: Camera.shake(float time, float x, float y)
Warning: This function has not yet been implemented.

sect3.title: set_pos (NYI)
sect3.para: Warning: This function has not yet been implemented.

sect3.title: set_mode (NYI)
sect3.para: Warning: This function has not yet been implemented.

sect2.title: Level
sect2.para: The Level class provides basic controlling functions for the current level.

sect3.title: finish
sect3.para: Ends the current level and marks it as completed if launched from a worldmap.
Tip: Very useful if you have created a frustrating level and want to, at some point, save the player from agony.

sect3.title: spawn
sect3.para: Respawns Tux in the sector sectorname at the spawnpointname spawnpoint.

Exceptions: If sectorname or spawnpointname are empty or the specified sector does not exist, the function will bail out first chance it gets. If the specified spawnpoint doesn't exist, Tux will be spawned at the spawnpoint named main. If this spawnpoint doesn't exist either, Tux will simply end up at the origin (top-left 0, 0).

sect3.title: flip_vertically
sect3.para: Flips the level vertically (i.e. top is now bottom and vice versa). Call again to revert the effect.
Tip: Make sure the player can land on something after the level is flipped!

sect2.title: ScriptedObject
sect2.para: A ScriptedObject is basically a SuperTux object that can be scripted to move around and animate. This object will be used in the SuperTux cutscenes a whole lot.

sect3.title: Usage notes
sect3.para:
Since a ScriptedObject is a reference object and not a statically declared object, you will have to build it into your level file, where a scriptedobject is a child of sector. This is an example definition:
(scripted-object (name "WOOT") (x 420) (y 94) (sprite "snowball") (solid #t) (physic-enabled #f) (visible #t) )

Now, the object can be accessed in code using the WOOT identifier like so:
WOOT.set_animation("left");

sect3.title: set_animation
sect3.para: Activates the sprite's animation specified in animation_name.

sect3.title: get_animation
sect3.para: Returns the name of the sprite's current animation.

sect3.title: move
sect3.para: Moves the object by x units to the right and y down relative to its current position.

sect3.title: set_pos
sect3.para: Basically identical to move, except its relativity to the sector origin.

sect3.title: get_pos_x
sect3.para: Returns the X coordinate of the object's position.

sect3.title: get_pos_y
sect3.para: Totally identical to get_pos_x except for its obvious choice of the other (Y) axis.

sect3.title: set_velocity
sect3.para: Makes the object move in a certain direction (with a certain speed) given by the x and y coordinates.

sect3.title: get_velocity_x
sect3.para: Returns the object's velocity in the direction of the X coordinate.

sect3.title: get_velocity_y
sect3.para: The difference between this function and get_velocity_x is just the same like between get_pos_y and get_pos_x: same thing, different coordinates.

sect3.title: set_visible
sect3.para: Shows or hides the object according to the value of visible.

sect3.title: is_visible
sect3.para: Returns true if the object is visible. (You've seen this coming, haven't you?)

sect3.title: get_name
sect3.para: Simply gives you the name of the scripted object (as if you didn't have it already...)

sect2.title: Sound
sect2.para: This class provides a very simple interface to the audio subsystem.

sect3.title: play_music
sect3.para: Plays the selected music track (automatically prepending the path to the music folder and appending the .ogg extension).

sect3.title: play_sound
sect3.para: Plays the sound specified in sound_name (that is identical to the filename of the sound without the .wav extension).

sect2.title: Text
sect2.para: This module provides access to methods reponsible for displaying text on-screen.

sect3.title: set_text
sect3.para: Sets the text string to be displayed to text.

sect3.title: set_font
sect3.para: Sets the font of the text to be displayed to text. Currently valid values are gold, white, blue, gray, big and small.

sect3.title: fade_in
sect3.para: Fades in the specified text for the next time seconds.

sect3.title: set_visible
sect3.para: Shows or hides the text abruptly (drastic counterpart to fade_in and fade_out).

sect3.title: set_centered
sect3.para: If centered is true, the text will be centered on the screen. Otherwise, it will be left-aligned.

sect2.title: Player
sect2.para: This module contains methods controlling the player. (No, SuperTux doesn't use mind control. Player refers to the player object.)

sect3.title: make_invincible
sect3.para: Makes the player invincible for a predefined amount of time.
See also: TUX_INVINCIBLE_TIME in src/object/player.hpp for the amount of seconds that the player becomes invincible.

sect3.title: deactivate
sect3.para: Stops the player and blocks the movement controls.
Tip: Don't call this in front of a horde of badguys.

sect3.title: walk
sect3.para: Makes the player move in a certain horizontal velocity (specified by velocity). A negative velocity moves the player to the left.
